> On Wed, 2003-03-12 at 15:01, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> If you have the discipline to turn EVERY debug session into at least
 > one automated test, then over time, debugging can be made sufficiently
> obsolete.

Now that you mention it, I don't think I have that discipline. But starting
today, I'll try :)

Sometimes, though, I don't think that discipline will help. I often use the
debugger to inspect variables in my test cases, e.g.:

  assertTrue( rainbow.contains( Color.orange ) );

If it fails, I have three choices for figuring out what rainbow contains so
I can start figuring out where orange went:

1. Put the color list into the assert message:

  assertTrue( "Expected rainbow to contain orange, but was: "
    + rainbow.colorListAsString(), rainbow.contains( Color.orange ) );


2. Put in a debugging string (BTW, this is what I thought the OP meant when
he said "logging", but of course I was wrong):

  System.out.println( "Rainbow: " + rainbow.colorListAsString() );
  assertTrue( rainbow.contains( Color.orange ) );


3. Put a breakpoint on the assert, and use the debugger to inspect rainbow's
contents.


#1 seems messy to me and requires a colorListAsString() method, #2 seems
really messy to me and still requires a colorListAsString() method. #3 is
clean and requires no extra code.


This is a contrived example, and it's possible that with better tests I'd
never get into this situation. I'm going to try to avoid the debugger for a
while and see what happens.


Erik Hanson
